ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned the most from any class at yale in this spanish class.
I learned more about the Hispanic culture and language structure.
Spanish grammar, writing skills, cultural information about Spanish-speaking countries
After taking this course, I gained the ability to hold a beginner level conversation in Spanish. I am also now able to write and read slightly higher than beginner level Spanish works.
I learned how to read, write, and speak Spanish at an introductory level.
My knowledge of and confidence in Spanish!
Learning elements of Spanish language and culture. Having the class every day also taught me about my learning habits and about the importance of keeping a schedule.

I am content with the amount of Spanish that I know after just taking Spanish 110 this semester. I knew more coming out of this class than I initially thought I would.

 I know how to hold basic conversations in Spanish and some writing/grammar rules. This was a great foundational course. Now I just need to expand my vocabulary and study irregular conjugations.
I learned much about the general construct of Spanish, basic grammar concepts, and Spanish culture! This was a great introductory course!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths was the professor and the vista learning. Very helpful in better understanding spanish. Weakness is just that some people come into the class knowing more/less spanish so it feels unfair.
Strength: the daily repetition was very helpful and good to retain the info. Weakness: could focus more on Hispanic countries

Strengths: Supersite, cultural lessons 

Weaknesses: Speaking practice, lots of assignments that are worth virtually nothing
Sections that allow a greater range of speaking with students and TAs would be helpful.

Strengths: I liked the Supersite and structure of the class generally. The asynchronous class on Wednesday with the discussion post was also nice and appreciate that it was structured around learning cultural elements / ideas we haven't seen in class.

Strengths:
* I like how discussion-based and collaborative this course is. It is good that we can talk to our peers and learn from each other and practice our Spanish improvement. I like that out final project was a group project, and I enjoyed working with my partners a lot.

Weaknesses:
*Because we covered so much content throughout the course, I feel that the harder content was glossed over more than it should have been- especially towards the end.

* I completely understand why Profe Russell talked in Spanish the whole time because that is how we learn. But if there are words we have not learned in Spanish yet, I feel as though what is said in Spanish would be clarified in English immediately after. For example, I would sometimes feel lost because Profe would tell is instructions for a Canvas assignment or class assignment in Spanish, but I didnt understand what he really said at all.

This course did a great job of introducing concepts, however, I feel that there were a few weaknesses. First, the amount of study time before exams was very short (we were often notified of exams only 2 or 3 days prior), thus, memorizing vocabulary can be very hard. Second, I wish there was more accountability for memorizing Spanish vocabulary (like weekly quizzes or a timeline for when we should know certain things). Third, I found the asynchronous Wednesdays to be largely ineffective. I wish there was more time spent on revising concepts and incorporating those into the Wednesday lessons, rather than writing in English mostly. 

There were a number of strengths, too! The smaller class size allowed for us to communicate and practice Spanish more, supersite was a very effective way of learning prior to classes, and Linguameeting was a great way to self-check our proficiency. I do think, though, that communicating with Spanish tutors at Yale or with fluent Spanish-speakers on campus would be more economical than purchasing Linguameeting sessions.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes definitely. I think it is so important to know spanish in this world.
Yes, Id recommend this course to anyone hoping to begin learning Spanish. I went in knowing absolutely nothing and walked away feeling like I knew so much.

I would recommend this course to students that are interested in learning Spanish or need to fulfill the language requirement. The class is pretty interesting and the course is structured in a way to facilitate engagement. Also, if you have Ian Russell he is super kind and helpful.
I would recommend this course. The course will bring a beginner student to a place where they have confidence in their Spanish speaking abilities.
Yes, it is an L1 Spanish course and important to establishing a foundation in advancing the language.

I would recommend this course to another student; It is definitely manageable. The only thing is that it is hard to keep up with Canvas assignments because their due dates are random. At first, I thought that the class was structured to where we only had asynchronous Canvas assignments on Wednesday, and then it seemed that it randomly switched up at a certain point- things were suddenly due on Tuesdays and Thursdays that I originally was not aware of.
Yes, I think this has been an incredible foundation to learning a new language!
